metadata.title: Synthesis of NiO Nano Octahedron Aggregates as High-Performance Anode Materials for Lithium Ion Batteries

sections.text:
Synthesis of NiO Nano Octahedron Aggregates as High-Performance Anode Materials for Lithium Ion Batteries
Chengzhi Wanga, Yongjie Zhaoa,*, Dezhi Sua, Caihua Dinga, Lin Wanga, Dong Yanb, Jingbo Lia, Haibo Jina,* aBeijing Key Laboratory of Construction Tailorable Advanced Functional Materials and Green Applications, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, PR China bDepartment of Mechanical Engineering and State Key Laboratory of Tribology, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, PR China
A R T I C L E I N F O
Article history: Received 2 November 2016 Received in revised form 31 December 2016 Accepted 11 February 2017 Available online 14 February 2017
Keywords: surface engineering NiO nano octahedron Li ion batteries anode materials
A B S T R A C T
The surface engineering strategy has exhibited unique advantages in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, sensing, etc. Here in this work, NiO nano octahedron aggregates with exposure of active {111} facets are synthesized through a facile and scalable way. When evaluated as anode materials for Li ion batteries (LIBs), the NiO nano octahedron aggregates exhibit excellent rate performance and long-life cycling performance with high reversible capability. A reversible capability of as high as 793 mA h g 1 is retained after 200 cycles at 0.2C. Moreover, the excellent rate performance is achieved. The exceeding lithium storage performance is attributed to the synergy effect of nano size and exposed (111) surface of the NiO octahedra improving kinetics of charge transportation and Li ion diffusion. The NiO octahedron aggregates can be used as prospective host materials for investigation of surface effect on catalysis, sensing, switching, supercapacitors and electrodes for sodium batteries, fuel cells, etc.
© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Electrochimica Acta
journal homepa ge: www.elsev ier .com/locate /e lectacta

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Surface structure engineering based on nanocrystals with regular geometries have attracted great attention exhibited unique excellence in photocatalysis [1,2], electrocatalysis [3,4], sensing [5], switching [6], Li ion batteries (LIBs) [7,8], etc. Especially, LIBs, as the widely used power source for portable electronics, will occupy a significant place in next-generation energy storage system [9,10]. The surface structure plays a significant role on the phase stability of nanosized Li+ insertion compounds and the voltage profile of cathode materials for LIBs [11]. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that the rate performance of cathodes for LIBs can be essentially improved through controlling the orientation or the exposure of specific crystal planes [3,12]. On the other hand, anode materials with specific surface structure have been less studied yet.
Nickel oxide (NiO) has been well-known in switching [12], magnetics [13], supercapacitors [14], catalysis [15], etc. and are expected as promising anode materials for LIBs because of its low cost, natural abundance, safety, and high theoretical specific capability of 718 mA h g 1 [16–18]. However, the application of NiO
* Corresponding authors. E-mail addresses: zhaoyjpeace@gmail.com, m0301050210@126.com (Y. Zhao),
hbjin@bit.edu.cn (H. Jin).
http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.electacta.2017.02.061 0013-4686/© 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
in LIBs was limited by its poor electrochemical performance [19,20]. Certain improvements have been achieved by engineering of various NiO nanostructures such as NiO nanoparticles [21], NiO nanofibers [22], NiO nanocone arrays on Ni foam [23], Co3O4-NiO nanoplates [24], mesoporous NiO microspheres [25], Ni/Co oxide hollow microspheres [26], NiO microflowers/grapheme composites [27]. However, nano-sized NiO polyhedra with exposed specific surface have been rarely investigated as anode materials for LIBs.
In view of surface engineering, herein NiO nano octahedron aggregates with exposed active {111} facets are synthesized through thermal decomposition of nickel hexagonal nanoplatebuilt microspheres, which is obtained via a facile and scalable solvothermal method. When evaluated as anode materials for LIBs, the NiO nano octahedron aggregates exhibit high reversible capability, long-life cycling performance and excellent rate performance.

sections.heading: 2.1. Synthesis of NiO nano octahedron aggregates
sections.text:
The NiO nano octahedron aggregates are synthesized through thermal decomposition of hexagonal nanoplate-built precursor
microspheres, which are obtained via a facile and scalable solvothermal method. Typically, 0.808 g of NiCl2 6H2O (3.4 mmol) is primarily dissolved in 5 mL DI water and 40 mL absolute ethanol under vigorous stirring with an addition of 0.5 g of polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) to get a green solution. Then 0.1 g of sodium hydroxide (NaOH) is added to the green solution while stirring. When a blur appears, the mixture is immediately sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (50 mL) and maintained at 200 C for 4 h. Following natural cooling to ambient temperature, the yellow products are washed with deionized water and ethanol for several times, and finally dried overnight at 60 C in an oven. Then the precursor microspheres are annealed at 450 C in air for 30 min to get the well-crystallized NiO nano octahedron aggregates.

sections.heading: 2.2. Material characterization
sections.text: The phase structure is analyzed by X-ray diffraction (XRD) on Bruker D8 Advance diffractometer with a Cu Ka radiation. Thermo gravimetric/differential thermal analysis (TG/DTA) is conducted on Netzsch STA 449C thermal analyzer in air with a heating rate of 10 C min 1. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Hitachi S-4800), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JSM-2100F) are used to observe the morphology and microstructure, respectively. To evaluate the specific surface areas (BET) and porosity distribution, the nitrogen adsorption isotherm is obtained on a NOVA4200e nitrogen adsorption apparatus (Quantachrome Instruments, USA). Raman spectra are obtained on an INVIA Raman microprobe (Renishaw Instruments, UK) with 514 nm laser excitation. The surface chemical states are analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (PHI Quanteral II, Japan) with Al Ka radiation as excitation.

sections.heading: 2.3. Electrochemical Measurements
sections.text:
CR2032-type coin cells are used to evaluate the electrochemical properties of the materials. To prepare the working anodes, the slurry composing of the active materials, acetylene black and polyvinylidenedifluoride (PVDF) binder with the weight ratio of 8:1:1 is pasted onto clean copper foil with the active mass loading of about 1.0 mg cm 2 and the thickness of around 60 mm followed by drying in a vacuum at 80 C for 12 h. The cells are assembled in an Ar-filled glove box with Li foil as the counter and reference electrode, polypropylene micro-porous film (Celgard 2300) as the separator, and a solution of 1 M LiPF6 in a mixture of ethylene carbonate (EC) and diethyl carbonate (DEC) (1:1 in volume) as the electrolyte. An eight-channel battery test system (LAND CT2001A) is utilized to obtain the discharge/charge profiles. Cyclic
voltammetry (CV) is performed over the potential range of 0.01–3 V at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s 1. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is carried out by applying an AC voltage with a sinusoidal signal of 5 mV in the frequency range from 0.01 Hz to 100 kHz. The CV and EIS are conducted on a CHI660E electrochemical workstation.

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
X-ray diffraction (XRD) is used to investigate the phase structure of the precursor and corresponding annealed product. Fig. 1(a) gives the XRD patterns of the precursor and the annealed NiO, respectively. Clear peaks are shown in the precursor XRD pattern, but these peaks are difficult to be identified. It can be explained that the precursor is a complex composite of hydrated chlorine-containing nickel hydroxide as the result of the incomplete precipitation of NiCl2 in alkali. The annealed NiO presents clear XRD diffraction peaks at 37.53 , 43.48 , 63.14 , 75.67 and 79.63 , corresponding to the cubic NiO (PDF#73-1519) crystal planes of (111), (200), (220), (311), and (222), respectively, which demonstrates the forming of highly crystalline NiO phase. The local structure of the precursor and the NiO is investigated by Raman spectra (Fig. 1(b)). Consistence with the XRD results, the broad upheaval in the precursor Raman spectrum indicates the complex and hardly-identified composite of the precursor, while the characteristic Raman peak of NiO at 500 cm 1 (longitudinal optical, LO) [28] indicates the forming of NiO for the product annealed at 450 C, which is used for further characterization.
The morphology and structure of the precursor and NiO are observed by SEM and TEM, respectively. As shown in Fig. 2(a) and (b), the precursor is composed of microspheres ( 2.2 mm), which are built by randomly crossed hexagonal nanoplates with an average thickness of 20 nm and side length of 140 nm. The NiO exhibits a hierarchical structure assembled by nano octahedra (Fig. 2(c)). The TEM images in Fig. 2(d) and (e) further reveals that the porous aggregates are composed of nano octahedra with smooth surface, sharp corners and an average egde-length of 80 nm, and the SAED pattern (inset in Fig. 2(e)) with bright NiO (200) and (111) diffraction spots confirms the forming of highly crystalline cubic NiO phase. Moreover, the HRTEM image of the octahedron in Fig. 2(f) shows a clear acute angle of the exposed surface and distinct lattice fringe. The d-space is measured by the inset FFT pattern to be 2.4 Å in agreement with (111) plane of cubic NiO phase. According to above results, the NiO octahedron aggregates are derived from the chlorine-containing nickel hydroxide hexagonal nanoplate microspheres through thermal annealing process. The confinement of the hexagonal nanoplates [29] and the chlorine ion releasing [30] during thermal
cursor and product annealed at 450 C, respectively.
process may play important roles on the formation of NiO nano octahedra.
The general synthesis route of NiO octahedron aggregates can be illustrated in Scheme 1. Firstly, the precursor of hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres is synthesized via a facile and
Scheme 1. Schematic illustration of the synthesis route of porous NiO aggr
scalable solvothermal method. NiO nano octahedron aggregates are derived from the well-synthesized hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres through an annealing process in air. The formation of the hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres is a temperaturedependent process under alkaline condition with the presentence
egates of nano octahedron enclosed by {111} facets of cubic NiO phase.
of PVP. A series of experiments are conducted under different hydrothermal temperatures (Fig. S2), PVP concentration (Fig. S3), NaOH addition (Fig. S4) to optimize the morphology. The morphology of the corresponding products under different conditions is characterized by SEM. It can be concluded that the hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres do not form until the hydrothermal temperature is above 180 C. Moreover, the PVP concentration plays a decisive role in the formation of microspheres, while the addition of NaOH induces the evolution of hexagonal nanoplates. The NiO nano octahedron aggregates result from the thermal decomposition of the hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres.
The surface chemical composition of NiO nano octahedron aggregates is analyzed by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). Fig. 3(a)–(c) show the survey spectrum, and high-resolution spectra of O 1s, Ni 2p, respectively. The survey spectrum (Fig. 3(a)) mainly exhibits contaminated carbon (C 1s), Oxygen (O 1s) and Ni species. In the O 1 s high-resolution spectrum (Fig. 3(b)), the two peaks at 531.8 eV and 529.4 eV indicates the presence of Ni OH band and Ni O band, respectively. The Ni 2p spectrum (Fig. 3(c)) shows two main peaks at 855.2 and 872.8 eV, which are assigned to Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively, with a spin-energy separation of 17.6 eV. Moreover, the satellite peaks (Ni 2p3/2, satellite: 860.8 eV; Ni 2p1/2, satellite: 878.8 eV) are observed as well. These results match well with other NiO-based materials [31], thus confirming the forming of NiO composite.
N2 absorption/desorption isotherms are measured to evaluate the specific surface areas and porosity distribution. Fig. 3(d) demonstrates the N2 absorption/desorption isotherms and the corresponding pore size distribution (inset) of the NiO nano octahedron aggregates. The isotherms belong to a type IV with a type H3 hysteresis loop, indicating a typical mesoporous structure. Based on the multi-point BET model, the specific surface area of the
NiO nano octahedron aggregates is calculated to be 21.528 m2g 1 with a total pore volume of 0.212 cm3 g 1. The pore size exhibits a broad size range from 1.54 nm to 109.60 nm with the most probable pore size of 2.59 nm and the average pore size of 38.01 nm according to the BJH model. The NiO with such high specific surface area and diverse porosity may provide unique favor for the rapid ion diffusion at the electrode/electrolyte interface and have the potential to be used as high-performance anode materials for LIBs.
The NiO octahedron aggregates are evaluated as anode materials for LIBs. The electrochemical performance is scientifically investigated. Fig. 4(a) shows the CV curves of the NiO anodes for the first five cycles at a scanning rate of 0.1 mV s 1 in the voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V. A sharp reduction peak at 0.31 V with a weak shoulder peak at 0.51 V is observed in the first cathode scanning. The peak at 0.31 V is ascribed to the conversion of NiO to Ni with the generation of amorphous Li2O and the formation of solidelectrolyte interface (SEI), while the shoulder peak is caused by structural destruction and disappeared in the subsequent cycles [32]. In the subsequent cycles, the reduction peak shifts near 1.0 V as a result of the drastic lithium-driven structural or textural modifications [33,34]. For the anodic scanning, the broad peaks at 1.1 V and 1.68 V can be explained as the structural change and the decomposition of Li2O, respectively, while the peak near 2.25 V is assigned to the oxidation of Ni to NiO [32–36]. Therefore, a conversion reaction is clearly demonstrated as follows [32,36]:
NiO þ 2Li$Ni þ Li2O Moreover, the stable and well-overlapped CV profiles after the second cycle implies the outstanding stability and high reversibility of the NiO anodes [32,36].
Fig. 4(b) exhibits the discharge-charge voltage profiles of the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 5th, 100th cycles for the NiO anodes in the voltage range of 0.01–3.0 V at a scanning rate of 0.2C (1C = 718 mA g 1). In
ano octahedron aggregates. (d) N2 absorption/desorption isotherms with pore size
the first discharge, the voltage slowly changes from the open circuit voltage of 2.35 V to 0.75 V, releasing a specific capacity of 450 mA h g 1, which results from the formation of lithiated NiO [32]. Then, the voltage reaches a plateau at 0.75 V, where the reduction of NiO to Ni occurs. This first-charge voltage plateau are not matching well with that in first cathodic CV scan. The difference may be caused by the difference in scanning mode and scanning rate for the battery test system and the electrochemical workstation, and this phenomenon are commonly shown in other NiO anodes [16,37]. Finally, a total discharge capacity of 1219 mA h g 1 is delivered, which is much higher than the theoretical specific capacity of 718 mA h g 1. The extra capacity is considered as the contribution from the formation of a polymer-like SEI layer [32–34].
The rate performance of the NiO anodes at different current density is presented in Fig. 4(c). As the current density enhances gradually from the initial 0.1C to 0.2C, 0.3C, 0.5C,1C and 2C, the NiO anodes delivers an average discharge capacity of 732 mA h g 1, 604 mA h g 1, 558 mA h g 1, 502 mA h g 1, 458 mA h g 1 and 388 mA h g 1, respectively. When the current density is reset to 0.1C, the average capacity can be recovered to the initial 732 mA h g 1 during the next 10 cycles. Further, the current density is again increased to 1C for another 40 cycles, then reverses back to the initial 0.1C. It shows that, not only the capacity of 474 mA h g 1 at 1C is retained for as much as 40 cycles, but the high capacity of 732 mA h g 1 at 0.1C reverts back once again. Therefore, the excellent rate performance, high reversibility and stability of the NiO anodes for high-current-density LIBs are demonstrated.
The cycling performance of NiO anodes is investigated by cycling in the voltage range of 0.01 to 3.0 V (vs Li+/Li) at a current density of 0.2C. As shown in Fig. 4(d), the first discharge/charge capabilities is 1219 mA h g 1 and 730 mA h g 1, respectively, with a Coulombic efficiency of 60.0%, which is mainly caused by the formation of SEI layer [34]. Then, the capability gradually decreases till the 43th cycle, where the capacity starts to climb up to
793 mA h g 1 at the 200th cycle. This phenomenon is generally explained as kinetically activation and enhanced interfacial lithium storage caused by the reversible growth of amorphous gel-like layer [38,39]. Finally, after 200 cycles the NiO anodes delivers a reversible capacity of as high as 793 mA h g 1 at 0.2C. Such high reversible capability and long-life cycling performance is comparable with that of previous NiO anode materials and other transition metal oxide nano octahedra anode materials (Table S1). The excellent performance should be attributed to the synergy of the exposed NiO (111) surface and nano size. The small size results in good contact between the active materials and electrolyte, thus facilitates the fast Li ion diffusion and the high exposure of {111} facets of the aggregated NiO nano octahedra with highly active reaction sites can accelerate the lithium conversion kinetics.
To better understand the exceeding performance of the NiO anodes, electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) is conducted. Fig. 6(a) shows the Nyquist plots of the NiO anodes for the fresh and 200th cycle. The plots are both exhibited the similar features: a high frequency intercept, two interconnected semicircles at the higher frequency end, and an oblique line in the low frequency region [35]. The high frequency intercepts represents the electronic resistance (Re) in the electrode. The first semicircle corresponds to the solid electrolyte interface (SEI) resistance (RSEI) in the electrode-electrolyte interfaces, while the other semicircle is attributed to the charge-transfer resistance (Rct) at the interface. The oblique line is caused by the Warburg impedance (W) corresponding to the lithium ion diffusion process in the anode materials. Moreover, the Li-ion diffusion coefficient (DLi-ion) can be estimated according to the following equations [40,41]:
Zre= Rct + Re + sv 1/2 (1)
DLi ion ¼ R2T2
2A2n4F4c2s2 ð2Þ
Table 1 Re, RSEI, Rct, and DLi-ion of the NiO anodes for selected cycles.
Cycle Re (V) RSEI (V) Rct (V) DLi-ion (cm2 s 1) fresh 2.7 4.95 54.5 3.39 10 14 200th 5.3 7.50 108.0 3.93 10 14
Fig. 6. SEM image and the corresponding EDS mapping of the NiO anode after 200th cycle at 0.2C in the presence of acetylene black and PVDF binder.
In Eqs. (1) and (2), v is angular frequency, R is the gas constant, T is the absolute temperature, A is the surface area of the electrode, n is the number of electrons per molecule during electrode reaction, F is the Faraday constant, c is the concentration of Li-ion in electrode, and s is the Warburg coefficient. The Warburg coefficients (s) are determined from the slope of the Zre-v 1/2 plots (Fig. 5(b)). The Nyquist plots are further fitted according to the electrical equivalent circuit (inset in Fig. 5(a)) and the Re, RSEI, Rct, and DLiion are given in Table 1. The initial small Re, RSEI, Rct imply the good contact with the electrolyte, which facilitates the charge transfer in the electrode. The increase of Re, RSEI, Rct after 200th cycle should be caused by the pulverization of the anode, like in other anode materials [8,26,27]. Notably, there appears a little increase from initial 3.39 10 14 cm2 s 1 to 3.93 10 14 cm2 s 1 of the DLi-ion after 200th discharge/charge cycle, indicating fast and stable Li ion diffusion in the anode. Therefore, it can be elaborated that the NiO nano octahedra with exposed (111) surface improve the kinetics of Li ion diffusion.
To clearly reveal the influence of the lithiation/delithiation process on the NiO anodes, the cells after 200th discharge/charge cycle at 0.2C (1 C = 718 mA g 1) are disassembled in the Ar-filled glove box and the anodes are repeatedly soaked in N,Ndimethylformamide (DMF) and acetone for several times to the NiO nano octahedron aggregates. The disassembled anodes are observed by SEM with corresponding EDS mapping (Fig. 6) in the presence of carbon black and PVDF binder. It can be seen that, the NiO octahedra with sharp corners and straight edges are maintained with some agglomeration as the result of repeatedly lithiation/delithiation induced structure reformation. The EDS mapping and corresponding element spectrum confirm the composite of the NiO octahedra.
According to the above results, it can be elaborated that the good cycling performance is not only attributed to the high surface area resulting from nano size, but also the exposure of highly active {111} surface effectively improving the kinetics of charge transportation and Li ion diffusion.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusion
sections.text:
In summary, NiO nano octahedron aggregates are synthesized through thermal decomposition of the well-synthesized nickel hexagonal nanoplate-built microspheres. The hierarchical NiO nano octahedron aggregates not only provide large surface area for fast Li ion diffusion between the anode and electrolyte, but the exposure of active {111} facets of NiO nano octahedra can effectively improve the kinetics of charge transportation and Li ion diffusion. The NiO anodes for LIBs exhibit high initial discharge
Fig. 5. (a) The Nyquist plot of the NiO anodes for selected cycles and the electrical equival very low frequency region (v: angular frequency, rad s 1).
capability (1219 mA h g 1 with initial Coulumbic efficiency of 60%), excellent rate performance (reversible capability of 474 mA h g 1 at 1C (718 mA g 1) for as much as 40 cycles), and long-life cycling performance (stable and reversible capability of 792 mA h g 1 at 0.2C for 200th cycle). Our work demonstrates that the NiO nano octahedron aggregates can be used as high-performance anode materials for LIBs and promising host materials for investigation of surface structure effect on catalysis, sensing, switching, supercapacitors and electrodes for sodium batteries, fuel cells, etc.
ent circuit (inset). (b) The corresponding linear relationship between Zre and v 1/2 at

sections.text: Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j. electacta.2017.02.061.

metadata.abstractText: The surface engineering strategy has exhibited unique advantages in photocatalysis, electrocatalysis, sensing, etc. Here in this work, NiO nano octahedron aggregates with exposure of active {111} facets are synthesized through a facile and scalable way. When evaluated as anode materials for Li ion batteries (LIBs), the NiO nano octahedron aggregates exhibit excellent rate performance and long-life cycling performance with high reversible capability. A reversible capability of as high as 793 mA h g 1 is retained after 200 cycles at 0.2C. Moreover, the excellent rate performance is achieved. The exceeding lithium storage performance is attributed to the synergy effect of nano size and exposed (111) surface of the NiO octahedra improving kinetics of charge transportation and Li ion diffusion. The NiO octahedron aggregates can be used as prospective host materials for investigation of surface effect on catalysis, sensing, switching, supercapacitors and electrodes for sodium batteries, fuel cells, etc. © 2017 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
